editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WAY TO GET MARRIED; A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.

p.hi: AUTHOR OF •• MBUS-ZORINSKI-CHILDREN IN THE WOOD, &

div.p:
LONDON: 〈◊〉
• OR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: Written by W. T. FITZGERALD, Eſquire.

sp.l: THE ſtage ſhould be, to life, a faithful glaſs,
Reflecting modes, and manners as they paſs;
If theſe extravagant appear to you,
Blame not the drama,—the reflection's true—
Our Author makes of virtue no parade,
And only ridicules the vice of trade;
Expoſes Folly in its native tint,
And leaves, mankind to profit by the hint.
The modern buck,—how diff'rent from the beau
In bag and ruffles, ſixty years ago!
The city coxcomb then was ſeldom ſeen,
(Conſin'd to Bunhill-row, or Bethnal-green:)
Weſt of Cheapſide you then could ſcarcely meet
The gay Lothario—of Threadneedle-ſtreet!
His folly rarely met the public eye,
Or, like a ſhadow, paſs'd unheeded by:
Tradeſman and rake were then remov'd as far
As gay St James's is from Temple-bar.
But now the cit muſt breathe a purer air,
The 'Change he viſits—lives in Badford-ſquare—
Inſures a fleet—then Bootle's club attends,
Proud to be notic'd by his titled friends;
And tries to join, by Diſſipation's aid,
The man of faſhion with the man of trade.
Vain to aſſociate with ſuperior rank,
He quits his ledger—for the Faro bank;
His daſhing curricle down Bond-ſtreet drives,
Riſking his own—and worſe—his horſes' lives;
Till, urging Fortune's glowing wheel too faſt,
This empty air-blown bubble breaks at laſt!
Tho' trade may give ſuch upſtart muſhrooms birth,
The Muſe pays homage to its real worth.
This iſle to commerce owes her ſplendid ſtate,
The ſource of all that makes her truly great!
And 'midſt her buſy ſons enough are found
To raiſe dejected mis'ry from the ground.
While commerce, with a lib'ral heart beſtows
Her wealth, to mitigate the poor man's woes;
Seeks out the wretch, his gloomy priſon cheers,
And wipes, with pitying hand, the widow's tears—
The applauding world will ſay (ſuch bounty giv'n)
The Engliſh merchant is the ſteward of heav'n.
Our Author now that candour would implore,
Which your indulgence has beſtow'd before;
Still on a gen'rous Public he depends;
Give your ſupport—he aſks no better friends!

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE
div.p: The Lines marked with inverted Commas are omitted in the Repreſentation

div.head: THE WAY TO GET MARRIED A COMEDY.
SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room in a Houſe—Bells ringing.

sp.speaker: DASHALL
sp.p: LANDLORD!

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Here I am—noiſy chap this.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Where are all your people? Damn it, Landlord, is this your attention?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Who do you damn, eh? If you don't like my houſe, march,—there's another in the town.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: This raſcal now, becauſe he has the beſt beds and wine on the road, claims the privilege of inſulting his gueſts—call my ſervants up.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Not I—enough plague with my own—why don't you go to the other inn? I'll tell you—becauſe you know when you are well off, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Impudent ſcoundrel! but as I want information, I muſt humour him.—You're a high fellow.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: An't I?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
And ſo, old Boar's head, my good friend, To by Allſpice, by the ſudden death of his predeceſſor,
enters this day upon the toniſh office of ſheriff of your ancient corporarion.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: He does.—And what's better, by the ſudden death of an old maid, miſs Sarah Sapleſs, he and his daughter will, it is ſaid, enter upon the fingering of about thirty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Good news, egad!—Well, old Porcupine, get dinner; and, d'ye hear, none of your ropy champagne—the real ſtuff (ſlaps him on the back.)

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Well, I will—Ecod, I like you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Come, be off (ſtrikes him with his whip.)

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Ecod, you have an agreeable way with you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: In the tickliſh ſtate of my circumſtances, Allſpice and his daughter will be worth attending to.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Letters, ſir, from London.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Now for it! this makes me a bankrupt, or a good man. (Reads) Dear Daſhall, all's up—As I thought.—Transfer ſwears if you don't ſettle your bear account in a week, he'll black-board you—Pleaſant enough!—Affectionate inquiries are making after you at Lloyd's; and, to crown all, Hops were ſo lively laſt market, that there is already a loſe of thouſands upon that ſcheme—Nothing can ſave you but the ready.—Yours, TIM. TICK.

N. B. Green peas were yeſterday ſold at Leadenhall-Market at nine-pence a peck; ſo your bet of three thouſand pounds on that event is loſt. So! lurch'd every way—ſtocks, inſurance, hops, hazard,
and green peas, all over the left ſhoulder; and then, like a flat, I muſt get pigeon'd at faro by ladies of quality; for the ſwagger of ſaying The ducheſs and I were curſt jolly laſt night; but, confuſion to deſpair! I'm no flincher.—If I can but humbug old Allſpice out of a few thouſands, and marry his daughter, I ſhall cut a gay figure, and make a ſplaſh yet.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: A room for Lady Sorrel.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What the devil brings her here?—Old and ugly as ſhe is, I'll take decent odds but 'tis an intrigue.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Inform my couſin Cauſtic, I'm here.— Ah! Daſhall, I ſuppoſe the warm weather has driven you from town.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: True; London was certainly too hot for me; but how could your ladyſhip leave the faſcination of play?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Huſh! that's not my rural character.—I always aſſimilate.—The fact is, Dick, I have here a ſtrange, plain-ſpoken, worthy, and wealthy relation; he gives me conſiderable ſums to diſtribute in London to the needy, which I loſe in play, to people of faſhion; and you'll allow that is giving them to the needy, and fulfilling the worthy donor's intention, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Then you are not here becauſe your favourite, young Tangent, is arrived? eh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p:
What, Dick, have you found out my attachment there? Well, I confeſs it: and if my regard be, not, I'll take care, my revenge ſhall be, gratified;
and 'tis a great conſolation that one is nearly as ſweet as the other.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And I'll be equally can did. The miſerable fact is, I am completely brozier'd, cut down to a ſixpence, and have left town.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Like a ſkilful engineer, who, having laid his train for the deſtruction of others, prudently retires daring the blow-up.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: In the next room, do you ſay? (Enters) Lady Sorrel, I rejoice to ſee you, and have provided at home for your reception.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Then I'll order my carriage and ſervants there.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: No; I can depend on your prudence, but not on your ſervants'—S'death! were any of your faſhionable London ſervants to get footing in my family, I ſuppoſe in a week my old houſekeeper would give conversationes, a little muſic, and twopenny faro.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Vaſtly well.—By no means contemptible.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Couſin, this is Mr. Daſhall, one of the firſt men in the city,—ſees the firſt company, lives in the firſt ſtyle—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: This a merchant of the city of London?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Curſe the quiz! Ill throw off a little—Perhaps you've not been in town lately.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: No, ſir,

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, the old ſchool quite gone by—I remember, my old gig of a father wore a velvet nightcap in his cornering houſe—what a vile bore, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, what may you wear in your compting houſe?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Strike me moral if I've seen it theſe three months. If you wiſh to trade in ſtyle, and make a ſplaſh, you muſt fancy Cheapſide Newmarket, and Lloyd's and the Alley faro tables, for Demoivre has as completely ouſted Cocker's Arithmetic with us, as Hoyle has the Complete Houſewife with our wives, egad—talk of Brooks's or Newmarket; chicken hazard to the game we play at Lloyd's—monopoly's the word now, old boy; hops, corn, ſugar, ſurs—at all in the ring.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Amazing! ſir, your capital muſt be aſtoniſhing to be—at all in the ring

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Capital! an old bugbear—never thought of now—no, paper—diſcount does it.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Paper!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye; ſuppoſe I owe a tradeſman, my taylor for inſtance, two thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: A merchant owe his-taylor two thouſand pounds! mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I give him my note for double the ſum, he diſcounts it—I touch half in the ready—note comes due—double the ſum again—touch half again, and ſo on to the tune of fifty thouſand pounds. If monopolies anſwer, make all frraight—if not, ſmaſh—into the Gazette. Brother merchants ſay "damn'd fine fellow—lived in ſtyle:—only traded beyond his capital. So, certificate's ſigned—ruin a hundred or two reptiles of retailers, and ſo begin the war again.—That's the way to make a ſplaſh—deviliſh neat, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How you ſtare! you don't know nothing of life, old boy.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Vulgar ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: We are the boys in, the city. Why, there's Sweetwort, the brewer,—don't you know Sweetwort? dines an hour later than any duke in the kingdom— imports his own turtle—dreſſes turbot by a ſtopwatch—has houſe-lamb fed on cream, and pigs on pine-apples—gave a jollification t'other day—Stokehole in the brewhouſe—aſked a dozen peers—all glad to come—can't live as we do. Who make the ſplaſh in Hyde-Park? who fill the pit at the opera who inhabit the ſquares in the weſt? why, the knowing ones from the eaſt to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Not the wife one's from the eaſt, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Who ſupport the faſhionable faro tables? oh, how the ducheffes chuckle and rub their hands, when they ſee one of us!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Ducheſſes keep gaming tables!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To be ſure! how the devil ſhou'd they live? ſuch a blow-up the other night! you were there, Lady Sorrel!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I at a ſaro table!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Upon my honour I beg pardon—you ſee, ſir, the ducheſs was dealing, and Mrs. Swagger was punting. Oh ho! cries Mrs. Swagger, "That was very neatly done"—"What do you mean?" ſays the ducheſs—"Only, madam, I ſaw you ſlip a card"—"dam'me" ſays the ducheſs—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Says the duke.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Says the ducheſs.

sp.speaker: Couſt.
sp.p: No, no! "dam'me," ſays the duke.

sp.speaker: Daſh
sp.p: Pſha! the ducheſs, I tell you. It's her way.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Her way! O Lud!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Where was I? oh, "dam'me," ſays the ducheſs, "but you turn out of my houſe"—"and curle me," cries little miſs Swagger, (a ſweet amiable little creature of about fourteen) "if we ſtay here to be ſwindled."—Words got high, and oaths flew about like rouleaus; but as they had plucked me of my laſt feather, I got up, and, in imitation of my betters, twang'd off a few dam'mes, and retired.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: The world's at an end—all is ſophiſticated!—nothing bears even its right name—whoredom is gallantry; ſwindling, running out; female debauchery, a faux-pas. The murdering duelliſt has a nice ſenſe of honour, the cuckold-maker is a dear delicious devil, and the cuckold the beſt humour'd creature in the world.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well ſaid, old one—you've ſome nous about you.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Foul-tongued blockhead!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell counſellor Endleſs I'll be in court preſently.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I think I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: So do I. (aſide)—'Tis your darling nephew, your adopted Tangent—I ſaw him come out of a chaiſe with two barriſters.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Pſha! barriſters! you forget he's in the army.

sp.speaker: Lady Ser.
sp.p: May'nt I truſt my eyes?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Why, at fifty-nine, couſin, eyes are not always to be truſted. Pray, Mr. Daſhall, do you know this nephew of mine?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh yes; but he aſſociates with authors and wits, quite out of our ſet—we in the city don't vote them gentlemen—you'll never find no wit at my table, I'll take care of that.—But you expect company, and ſo I'll be off to my friend Allſpice's.—By the way, I hear his daughter will touch to the tune of thirty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Cauſt
sp.p: Very likely: but I don't know any good it will do • er.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Not do good! I beg pardon. Riches gives wit,—elegance.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Do they? I'm ſorry you're ſo poor.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Eh! what! oh neat enough! and what do you ſay riches give, queer one?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Generally, vulgar impertinence.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I congratulate you on being ſo rich, ha, ha! rat me! but at laſt I've ſaid a good one. Lady Sorrel, your devoted.—Good bye, queer one!—What a ſuperlative gig it is!

sp.speaker: Cauſt
sp.p: Was that my nephew's voice?
Sir, your moſt obedient!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, my dear uncle! who could have expected to have ſeen you in this part of the world?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
This part of the world! why, 'tis the town
I live in, is it not? and have not you come on purpoſe to viſit me?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: True, uncle; I was—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: At your old tricks, caſtlebuilding. Fancying yourſelf Tippoo Saib, I warrant, or empreſs of all the Ruſſias.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, no, you wrong me—Ah, lady Sorrel, how cou'd you leave town, where you were the ton?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: The ton, ha, ha! Then I ſuppoſe grandmothers are the ton?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You have hit it, uncle, (aſide to Cauſtic)—l never ſaw you look ſo well.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Dear ſir, you ſlatter.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: He does, he does. Come, ſir, no more of that. Age is reſpectable, and you ought to be above making a jeſt of an old woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, your behaviour is intolerable. Mr. Tangent, do you dine with us?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nothing can afford me greater felicity—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Than to dine with an old woman—Nonſenſe! Go home, couſin, go home.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Brute! Mr. Tangent, good morning. Sweet, elegant youth! how my heart doats on him.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Frank, leave that curſed trick, that—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I know what you mean—I believe I uſed to indulge in little flights of fancy.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: You did indeed.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, that's all over, My life paſſes in a dull conſiſtent uniformity.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I'm glad on't—Well, how goes on the regiment?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The regiment? Oh, I've left the army. Cauſt, Oh, you've left the army, (imitating)—and why, ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I don't know—I imagine I was tired of the routine, field-days, parade, meſs-dinners, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And ſo what, ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang
sp.p: I determined to adhere to the law.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I've no patience with your ſolly. But, ſir, are you ſure the law has brought you here? Is it not ſome ridiculous love affair, ſome jilting tit from Exeter?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll humour his diſlike to the ſex.— Women. Gewgaws for boys and dotards.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: True. He has a fine underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What are they all?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Ay; what are they all?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The beſt of them are virtuouſly vicious, and impertinently condeſcending.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: He's a fine youth.—Go on.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: All a contradiction.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: True, Frank; Pope himſelf ſays ſo—
sp.l: "Woman's at beſt a contradiction ſtill;
sp.p: then he goes on—
sp.l: "A ſop their paſſion, and their prize, a ſot."

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: "Alive, ridiculous; and dead, forgot."— Sir, I've the whole epiſtle by heart.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
Have you? Come to my arms. Now ſtick
to this and the law, and my whole fortune is your own—when I die.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And in the mean time I'll thank you for a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Thank me! I dare ſay you will. A thouſand pounds! But how is it to be employed?—What faſhionable ſcheme

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A very unfaſhionable one; uncle; in paying my debts.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: You know, Frank, you once diſgraced yourſelf, and deeply offended me, by borrowing money of M'Query, a knaviſh money-lender. If your debts are of that deſcription, you become my antipathy, my deteſtation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: On my honour, no.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Well then, as I can better afford to loſe it, than an honeſt creditor, I'll give it you on conditions—firſt, that you adhere to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Granted.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Secondly, that you leave that hair-brain'd folly, which makes me mad,—that caſtle building.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, granted.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And laſtly, that this thouſand ſhall be the ſum total of your extravagance.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: With all my heart—And here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: But, Frank, what ſay you to 30,000l. down on the nail?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I ſay, ſir, that no particular objection to it ſtrikes me at preſent.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
Then I'll tell you—Here's a will by which it is ſuppoſed miſs Clementina Allſpice will be heireſs
to that ſum. Now I'll introduce you: and if, on ſeeing her, you agree with me that ſhe is groſsly vulgar, and extravagantly affected,—in ſhort, ſhould you thoroughly diſlike her, I can ſee no rational objection to your marrying her.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Certainly not—I'll attend you; but firſt I muſt go to the courts.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Aye, ſtick to the law—ſtick to that—ſtick to any thing. You remember your pranks—This hour writing a ſatire on the ſrivolity of the age, the next, riding a hundred miles to ſhoot at a target —One day dreſt in ſolemn black for the purpoſe of ordination The next in a pink jacket and jockey cap, riding a match at Newmarket—So, no more of that, but ſtick to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: To be ſure; what expanſion of intellect it occaſions! What honours does it not lead to!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Think of the woolſack.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: There's an object to look to!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: My ambition anticipates my honours, and I ſee myſelf in the envied ſituation.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dreſs'd in my robes, I bow to the throne.
sp.stage: (Sits down with dignity in a chair.)

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Zounds! now he's at it.
sp.stage: (Tangent riſes and puts on his hat.)
sp.p:
Order! Order! Is it your lordſhips pleaſure this bill
do paſs—As many as are content, ſay, "Aye"—Not content, "No"'—The contents have it.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Now would it not provoke the devil?— I humbly move that your lordſhip may leave the woolſack, and that your brains may ceaſe to go a woolgathering.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: My lord!—Eh!—Oh!—I beg your excuſe, uncle—I was juſt indulging a little flight.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Yes, I know you were But where are you going?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: To the courts.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Pray ſtick to the law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And to the woolſack. Does not the hope of that fill our univerſities with blockheads—and cram our courts full of barriſters, with heads as empty as they leave their clients' pockets?—As many as are content, ſay "Aye" Not content, "No"—The contents have it.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: So mad and abſurd as ever! But I truſt he has a good heart, and I'll give him fair play; for, ſometimes, the ſubſiding oppoſition of worth and folly produces the brighteſt characters, even as the beautiful firmament is ſaid to have been formed from the contending chaos of light and darkneſs.

div.head: SCENE II. FAULKNER'S HOUSE—A knocking at the door, Faulkner croſſes the ſtage, and opens the door.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, my maſter (Mr. Cauſtic) will wait on you this morning for the payment of his rent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My compliments, and I ſhall be glad to ſee him.

Thank heaven; enough remains for that▪ My rent being paid, perhaps I may gloſs over the meagre hue of poverty, till my law-ſuit is decided. (A barp is brard) Poor Julia! did'ſt thou know thy father's abject penury, 'twoud break thy heart. Perhaps it may be concealed at leaſt I'll try to think ſo—Julia! my daughter!
My deareſt father!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My child! thou art this day of age.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, (averting her face with dejection, then recovering berſelf.)—I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Heireſs of penury. My darling girl! Oh, had heaven ſo will'd it, this had been a morning that pleaſure might have long'd for. The ſad reverſe made ſleep a ſtranger to me. I roſe, and gave thee, Julia, all a poor fond father could,—a bleſſing at the throne of mercy.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: More rich, more valued than all the ſplendour we have loſt. Indeed I grieve not for it. Pray, ſir, be cheerful, as we are above the reach of want.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh! (ſtiſting a groan) True, my love; return to your harp—I expect my attorney—he diſpatch'd, I'll come to thee—Sure he ſtays!—What ſays my watch?—hold—I forgot I had parted with it

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How fortunate! Look, ſir, I've made a purchaſe for you (ſhewing a watch). Since you loſt yours, you have been leſs punctual in coming home, and I have been the loſer of many a happy hour—'Tis quite a bargain the man will call to day for die money.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: How unlucky!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: You are not angry? You cannot be! What, not a kiſs for my attention?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My only comfort! (kiſſes her) Here's a bank note—Pay for your purchaſe, and employ the reſt in procuring our houſehold wants. Go in—a thouſand bleſſings on thee.
Poor, luckleſs wench! Oh, how willingly would I lay down this life, but for thy ſake, my child
Captain Faulkner!
sp.stage: (Faulkner goes to the door and opens it).

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah, my attorney! Speak, tell me, relieve the ſufferings of a parent's heart am I to deſpair? (M'Query ſhakes his head) Is there a hope?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Here's a letter.

stage.hi: (Faulkner of opens it with trepidation and gives it to M'Query.)

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Pray read it.

sp.speaker: M'QUERY
sp.p: Sir I am Fau'k. Pray read ſorry, that inſtead of congratulating you " on the recovering your valuable eſtates, I have to "inform you, that by an unlucky, and accidental "error in our declaration we were non-ſuited. I muſt "trouble you to remit me 2001. as I cannot in pru-dence undertake the continuance of this important " cauſe without the coſts being ſecured to me your " faithful ſervant, DEDIMUS DUPLEX."

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ruin, Ruin!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, here's a bit of a poſtſcript—" A Mr. Tangent—"

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: MQuary.
sp.p: What's the matter? (reads)"A Mr. Tangent has been frequently inquiring after you."

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: How unlucky!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That you did not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: y—ye—yes— ſir—

sp.speaker: McQuery
sp.p: How lucky then! for I ſaw him juſt now.
Flulk. In this town? M'Query. Yes; I'll bring him here in a crack

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hold! not for the world.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p:
Not for the world! what makes you tremble? Oh, ho! there's a bit of a ſecret, and I muſt be maſter of it (aſide.) Come, an't I your friend?
Did not I come and offer my friendſhip and aſſiſtance, without even knowing you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You did ſo.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And an't I ſtill ready with my friendſhip and ſervice?—and I will aſſiſt you.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Will you, will you, ſir? Indeed I want it. Hear then my unhappy ſtory; but ſwear by ſacred honour.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If you've a bit of a bible, I'll take my oath—honour's all moonſhine!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, ſir. Honour, is the converſation of ſociety: without it, even our virtues wou'd be dangerous. It tempers courage, and vice it puts to ſhame; it irradiates truth, and mixes up oppoſing paſſions in the ſweet compound of urbanity.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, very true; (aſide) I'll pop that into my next brief. Oh, it will make a flaſhy ſpeech for one of our fine pathetic barriſters. But now for the ſecret. Whatever you communicate ſhall be locked here, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
It was my fate to marry contrary to my father's will, and I was driven by misfortune to India; where, after a reſidence of eighteen years, the news reached me of my father's deceaſe, and that at his death he had done me the juſtice he refuſed me living. I was about to return to England to take poſſeſſion of my eſtates, when the ſervice demanded my aſſiſtance to check the inroads of a powerful banditti that infeſted the frontier.—In a ſkirmiſh, Lieutenant Richmond, a brave
lad, fell by my ſide—he gave to my care one thouſand pounds, as a bequeſt to his friend Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: So far, ſo well.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: On my return, ſir, I found my wife dying. I am ſorry to trouble you with hearing my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Don't mention it—'tis a pleaſure—you found your wife dying.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And my patrimony, as you know, uſurped by a diſtant and wealthy relation—I endeavoured to find Mr. Tangent—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh no!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Indeed I did, ſir—diſtreſſes came upon me—arrears for my daughter's education—the expences of my wife's funeral.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Nobody wou'd grudge that, ſure.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And the hopes of recovering my right by law, induced me, ſir, to, to—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Make uſe of Mr. Tangent's money.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Y—yes—ſir. I doubted not but I cou'd ſoon replace it. I had conſiderable prize-money due— aye, and ſomewhat hardly earn'd—but it is not paid. Involved with agents, proctors—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Aye, and ſweet pretty picking it is.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I hoped ſoon to recover my eſtates. But the progreſs of the law, is, you know, ſo very ſlow—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: We don't—we don't hurry ourſelves certainly.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, ſir, wou'd you advance the money to pay Mr.—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Why, you don't mean to pay it, do you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Don't bother yourſelf about ſuch a trifle— pay him! pugh! ſtuff! Between ourſelves, I thought you had been dabbling in a little forgery.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Villain! (ſeizes him. M'Query ſmiles) Oh. I beg pardon—you are pleaſant.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes, I am very pleaſant; and I wiſh I cou'd return the compliment. (aſide) What a tiger! However, I'm glad you have the caſh, becauſe—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Even now, I gave the laſt guinea I poſſeſſ'd to my daughter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's unlucky! Becauſe here's a little bit of a bill for labour, trouble, care and diligence, as we ſay.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This, then, is your proffer'd aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh, read it, read it. You'll find it right to an eightpence.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: "Attending you frequently to offer my advice and friendſhip without being able to meet you, two pounds two."

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's right and proper, and 'tis all like it; but as you've no caſh, you may as well ſign a little bit of a bond and judgment: it will make the debt an even fifty.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, any thing.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity you're ſo poor.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Huſh! for heaven's ſake—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'm worth twenty thouſand.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You're a lucky man, ſir.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Here's a bond ready.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Within there! Bring pen and ink.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Ha, ha! You forget you have not a parcel of ſervants now. That's a good one, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ha, ha! I did ſo, ſir.—Damnation! is life worth holding on theſe terms? We ſhall find them in the next room.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Now, ſir, tho' you have put yourſelf in my power—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hah! in your power—ſhallow fool! mark me. Dare but to hint at what I've told you, and by the honour I have loſt, your life pays the forfeit—do you mark? In your power! Do you mark, I ſay?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: O yes! I was not in earneſt. I was pleaſant again. Oh, what a devil he is! 'tis hard to be ſo poor—I'm worth twenty thouſand, every ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This way. Unfeeling man!

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Clementina.
sp.p: How do I look, Fanny? Do you know, Fanny, my dead aunt was quite teizing—I declare and vow ſhe once ſent for me to ſee her die, and I found her dancing a Scotch reel at an aſſembly. How horrid provoking! Have you an idea, Fanny, how much one ought to cry for an aunt?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I dont really know, miſs.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh Fanny, you lived with lady Eſchallot when her huſband died. Did ſhe make it a point to take on?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: O yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Did it tell, Fanny?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Exceedingly, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I dare ſay it wou'd be ſtyliſh, 'tis ſo particular. Oh! I ſhall have oceans of lovers when I get this fortune. 'Tis ſo ſhocking to be conſtant, I vow— after you have cut your jokes and ſhown your tricks, it grows ſo inſipid, and you do long for another lover
in ſuch a ſtyle, you've no idea. Here comes pa—Do you know, Fanny, that pa's keeping a ſhop horrifies me to that degree—

sp.stage: Enter ALLSPICE, with his velvet cap and apron on.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ah, Cleme—what! dizen'd out—expect to touch the mopuſſes, eh?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Indeed, pa, I'm reduc'd to deſpair to ſee you out of mourning.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Firſt let's ſee the will. Time enough to mourn when I find there's ſomething to rejoice at. I wiſh Cauſtic would come—buſy day, Cleme. As ſheriff, I muſt uſher the judges into the town—as tradeſman, muſt attend my cuſtomers—ſo, what between the judges in the court, and the old women in the ſhop, I've my hands full.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, and Mr. M'Query, ſir.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ah, friend Cauſtic, glad to ſee you—ſervant, Mr. Attorney—come, bring chairs, read quick, —never mind ſtops—buſy day.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Miſs Clementina, how do you do? Theſe are rather gay habiliments for mourning.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, no obſervations. As pa ſays, read.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: With all my heart—except the colour, gay as a bride.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dont be impertinent, man.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And the head too—heigho! Well, here is the will, and thus I break the ſeal—now for it.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ay, now for it.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I, Sarah Sapleſs, ſpinſter, being of ſound and diſpoſing mind, do make this my laſt will and teſtament. Imprimis, I bequeath to my worthy brother-in-law, Toby Allſpice.—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe was an excellent old woman!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: "Toby Allſpice, the ſum of five pounds—"

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: "The ſum of five pounds, to purchaſe a ring."

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: A ring.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Fiddlededee! Superannuated old fool.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Silence! And whereas my wayward fate has deprived me of the comforts of wedlock, and as I sincerely believe that nothing can tend more to the benefit of ſociety, than promoting the happineſs of faithful lovers—very extraordinary this!—I do hereby bequeath to Walter Caustic, eſquire, all my eſtates, perſonal and real—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I bequeath to Walter Cauſtic, eſquire, all my eſtates, perſonal and real,—in trust—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, in truſt!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I hate truſts.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Silence, ſir. Go on.

p.q: In truſt, to ſettle and convey the ſame as a marriage portion upon any young woman he may think worthy, who may be about to become a bride, within the ſpace of one month after my deceaſe.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ecod, its a queer one.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: "And whereas—"

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That's 'all that's material, except a bit of a codicil.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, is not my name in the will?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, miſs.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Pa!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Cleme!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know, pa, that being diſappointed of thirty thouſand pounds, is extremely diſagreeable?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Very, Cleme.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: All that's material? What's this, and this?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: That, you know, is deſcription and ſpecification; and ſaying it over and over again, to make the thing look plump and decent.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Now for the codicil! I, the within named, Sarah Sapleſs, do make this codicil, which I do order and direct may be taken as part of my ſaid will, and by which I do hereby bequeath to Phelim M'Query, my attorney, in lieu of his bill, one thouſand pounds— Very moderate recompenſe!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Very moderate! But 'tis enough—Oh, 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
This, certainly is the moſt extraordinary;
Ha, ha, ha! To ſelect me for the high prieſt of Hymen, to make me a wither'd Cupid, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: The cavalcade is ready to move, and only waits for your honour.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Then get my gown and wig; and my white wand. 'Tis very awful!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: You look alarm'd—I've ſeen you before a judge without being frighten'd.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Aye; but that was when I was a greater man than the judge, foreman of the jury—and then I'm not afraid of the devil.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If you don't think my diffidence may increaſe yours, I'll attend.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Oh, no danger!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Well, now I commence the perfect gemman. Damn it, ſtand back, (to M'Query) I muſt go firſt. Dick, fill this box with backy—Roger, yoke the coach.

div.stage: CAUST. is going, when CLEM, curtſies, and ſtops him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, you were polite enough to find fault with my dreſs—I'll alter my gown any way you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: So, here's a change! (aſide) By no means, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But you have diſcernment, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I have a little, ma'am. (ſarcaſtically) Good morning.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: When may we expect the honour of ſeeing you again, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Tangent will be here. Miſs Clementina, I intend to introduce to you my nephew, Mr. Tangent. Should he come before I return, I hope you'll welcome him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dear ſir! Oh! oh! Mr. Tangent and I, then, are to be the happy pair. (aſide) Dear Mr. Cauſtic, I hope you have quite abandon'd your gout. I declare and vow, I was horrified at hearing you were ill.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I expected death.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know that's extremely diſagreeable. I hope you will make it a point to keep well, Mr. Cauſtic. Pray take care of the ſteps—If you ſhou'd ſlip, I ſhou'd ſcream in ſuch a ſtyle, you have no idea. I muſt attend you.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: You are too good. No.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I ſhall expire if I don't. Take care, dear Mr. Cauſtic.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p:
I'm afraid ma'am, you'll find the parcel rather
ther heavy—I'll ſend it home. There's your change, ma'am.
sp.stage: Enter TANGENT (ſits down in a chair).

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Shopman, is Mr. Cauſtic here?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: He's gone, ſir; but will return preſently.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very well—I'll wait for him.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: You'd better walk into the houſe, ſir:—the ſhop—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I like the ſhop. Is your miſtreſs, miſs Clementina within, oh!

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I don't much reliſh this affair. However, it humours old Cauſtic ſo,—d'ye hear? tell her Mr. Tangent wiſhes to pay his reſpects—What are you about?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Oh. I dare not go before miſs with my apron on—ſhe ſays its vulgar.
sp.stage: Exit. (after having put his apron on the chair)

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ignorant prejudice! (putting the apron round him) By heavens, 'tis as honeſt an appendage, aye, and of as much benefit to ſociety too, as many long robes I've ſeen. (ſets) Tired to death of the courts—either as dull as a country church, or as vulgar as Billingſgate.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I preſume, ſir, you belong here.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I, ma'am! heavens, what an angel! Ma'am—No— (looking at himſelf) Oh yes—
yes, ma'am—I belong to the ſhop. (throwing away his hat) What a lovely creature!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is Mr. Richard at home?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, ma'am, Dicky has juſt ſtept out, ma'am—Intereſting beyond deſcription!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Then I muſt trouble you for theſe articles.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Proud to ſerve you, ma'am—juſt take down the day-book—now I ſhall know my angel's name and abode. To be ſent, ma'am, to—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There's ſomething very extraordinary in this young man—Sir, I'll ſend for them—Good morning.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: S'death! I ſhall loſe her—Stop, ma'am, I beg pardon—but here are exactly the articles you want, ready packed, and I ſhall be happy in attending you home with them, ma'am—exceedingly happy.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: His deportment and dreſs ſeem much above his ſituation—Sir I can't think of troubling you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Trouble, ma'am! Never above my buſineſs. I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But there is none to attend the—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am, Dicky is only in the houſe. What ſhall I do for a hat? (Sees a ſmall one hanging up, puts it on) Ma'am, I'll follow you—Dicky, mind the ſhop, Dicky—Oh, an angel! What the devil have I got here? 'tis infernally heavy. I'll follow you, ma'am—Dicky, take care of the ſhop.

div.stage: Enter CLEM. (with her eyes fix'd on the ground) and SHOPMAN.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, your moſt obedient—I declare and vow— (Looks up, then at the ſhopman) Where's Mr. Tangent, fellow?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: I left him here, ma'am, with my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then he's gone.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Ecod, and ſo is my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Now, whether this is ſhocking vulgar, or extremely ſtyliſh, I've not the minuteſt atom of an idea. I dare ſay 'tis genteel.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Not to take my apron.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, I'm ſure 'tis fine breeding; for there's a certain brutality in high life that's enchanting. (huzza without) What horrid yell is that?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: 'Tis my maſter, the ſheriff, miſs, come from the ſhow, huzza!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Silence, brute!

div.stage: Enter ALLSPICE (with ſheriff's gown and wig, wiping his face).

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Thank God 'tis over! I'd rather throw a hundred ſugar loaves into a cart, than go thro' it again. Well, Cleme, how goes on the ſhop?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You know, pa, I hate the ſhop.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p:
Oh fie, Cleme! don't let me hear you ſay that again. You dog, is that the way to tie up a parcel? (to ſhopman, and gives a box on the ear) Confound
theſe trappings! Get me my apron, Cleme, will you?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I declare and vow, pa, your vulgarity horrifies me. Suppoſe you were to go to court with an addreſs, and be knighted, wou'd not your manners—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Me knighted! Fiddleſtick's end. When ſuch chaps as I go to get dubb'd, if, inſtead of a ſword, his majeſty wou'd but order one of his beef-eaters, to lay a ſtick acroſs our ſhoulders, it wou'd be a hundred percent the better.

div.stage: Enter ſheriff's ſervant, dreſt in the abſurdity of lace, large hat, &c.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Maiſter!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. ſheriff, Brute!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You ſee I bes dizen'd out in new livery, he, he!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Take off your hat, ſavage.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I canna, miſs—Man has ſtuckn'on ſo faſt, he winna came off—he, he!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Geoffry, 'tis hard to tell whether you or I look moſt ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ecod, maiſter, I think you have it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Who's at the door?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Wauns I forgot. It be maiſter Daſhall fra Lunnun.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, my friend, Daſhall—ſhow him in. But let me get off theſe trappings—The Londoner will ſmoke me.
Ah, Daſhall! Glad to ſee you. Ecod, you look comical tho'. Why, Dick, either your head or mine muſt be deviliſhly out of faſhion—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Why, friend Toby, yours is more on the grand pas to be ſure. But very little head, you ſee, ſerves people of faſhion. So—there's the thirty thouſand pounder, I ſuppoſe. I ſay, Toby, who is that elegant creature?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: 'Tis my daughter. Don't you remember Cleme!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: You're an angel!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Go, Cleme, and look after the people—To day, I give grand—ga ga—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gala, pa! I've told you the name twenty times—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Confound it! Gala then.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt devoted.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I adore you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh, ſir!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To diſtraction, damme.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I vow you confuſe me in ſuch a ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, I ſee that account's ſettled— (looking after her) and now for the father. Oh, how does it tell?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What, that's the knowing, is it?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To be ſure. But, Toby, how did you come on at the courts?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, capitally. I made a ſpeech

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes, I did. Sam Smuggle you muſt know was found guilty of taking a falſe oath at the Cuſtom Houſe; ſo the judge order'd me to put Sam in the pillory. "An pleaſe you, my lord judge," ſays I, "I'd rather not." "Why ſo, Mr. ſheriff?" Becauſe, my lord, ſays I, "Sam Smuggle, no more than a "month ago, paid me 37l. 18s. 11d. as per ledger, and I make it a rule never to diſoblige a cuſtomer"—Then they a laughed—So you ſee I came off pretty well.

sp.speaker: Deſh.
sp.p: Capitally. But an't you tired of this ſneaking retailing

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ſometimes of a Saturday—Market day.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: 'Tis a vile paltry bore. What do you make by this raffiſh ſhop of yours?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, a great deal. Laſt year 1745l. odd money.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Contemptible! my clerk wou'd deſpiſe it. Why, in a ſingle monopoly I've touch'd ten times the ſum.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Monopoly?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To be ſure—the way we knowing ones thrive. You remember that on ſugar—a firſt rate thing, was it not?—diſtreſſed the whole town—made them take the worſt commodity at the beſt price: netted fifteen thouſand pounds by that.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Why, I turned the penny by that myſelf.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Turned the penny! be adviſed by me, and
you ſhall turn thouſands,—ay, and overturn thouſands.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Shall I tho'? but did you ſell all that ſugar yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I fell! never ſaw a loaf. No, my way is this—I generally take my firſt clerk a hunting with me; and when the hounds are at fault, we arrange theſe little matters.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: How free and eaſy! oh, you muſt be gloriouſly rich.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I won't tell you my circumſtances juſt now.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh you're ſly—you've your reaſons.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I have. I'm very expenſive in my women tho'.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ah! mothers and ſiſters extravagant?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Mothers and s;iſters! no, no.—Curſe me if I know how they carry on the war. Take in the flats at faro I ſuppoſe. No, I mean, the girls.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What! not concubines, do you?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To be ſure. But perhaps you don't like the girls, eh?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh but I do tho'—I'll tell you a melancholy ſecret. Do you know that people in the country are ſo preciſe, and talk ſo about character, that, my dear friend, in the particular you mentioned, I am a very unhappy man.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, is it there I have you? then come to town, my gay fellow, enjoy affluence and pleaſure, and make a ſplaſh.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p:
Ecod, I ſhou'd like it. Even talking about
it, gives me a kind of ſwaggering, agreeable feel: and then the girls—the pretty profligates!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, you ſhall have my Harriet.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Shall I? I'll do all I can to make her happy, yes, I will: and if ſhe likes almonds and raiſins, ſhe ſhall have—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Almonds and raiſins! pearls and diamonds!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes; but how am I to get them?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: You've heard of the Alley?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes; but I don't underſtand it. Bulls and bears—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I'll make you up to all—Cons—Reſcounters, ſhort ſtuff, bonus, backwardation, omnium gatherum—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Aye; and what's being a lame duck?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I'll ſhew you the way to be that too. I'll teach you the true waddle—let you into twenty good things beſides. We knowing ones have form'd a moſt capital plan for ſtarving the nation.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Aye, but you forget that other knowing ones have formed a capital plan for preventing the ſtarving of the nation.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Still I've a reſource.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Have you? egad, you're a clever fellow.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Come here.—If corn market don't anſwer, ſhip it coaſtwiſe—inſure it—veſſel leaky—ſtreſs of weather—come to an anchor—cut out by an enemy's privateer—all ſettled before-hand—receive value of cargo there—touch inſurance at home—do them both ways—knowing ſcheme.—The inventors will be immortal.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: And if I had my will, they ſhould be immortal in a week. Supply an enemy! dam'me if I do that.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, ho! bad voyage this, I muſt about ſhip.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: I love money dearly and I love the pretty girls, but—

sp.speaker: Daſh,
sp.p: And Harriet will adore you.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, do you ſay ſo? I tell you what I'll do—I'll ſtart gallant to day—I'll make a ſplaſh among the ladies at my—what's the name on't?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Gala. But you muſt get rid of that porcupine frizzle. You muſt be cropt in this way.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Bleſs you, I've plenty of hair under my wig.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: That's lucky (aſide)—So—I've got him pretty tight in hand.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: You'll ſee how I'll ogle and ſwagger. Come along. Oh, Toby's the boy to tickle them.

div.head: SCENE II. A Room in FAULKNER'S Houſe,

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Does my attorney in town refuſe to proceed?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Without caſh he does.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: He knows the law is with me to a certainty.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Law and certainty! you really forget what you are talking about.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Moſt likely: far I am mad.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for you, Captain, indeed I am; tho' I'm only an attorney, I'm ſorry.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, don't outrage your tender nature.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, your moſt obedient—I call'd, ſir, respecting—but you're engaged.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, be ſeated.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: My buſineſs, ſir, is of ſo little importance either to you or myſelf, that—he ſeems agitated—I'll take another opportunity—good morning—I'll juſt take a peep into the courts, and ſee how Tangent comes on in the law—oh, he'll be chancellor.

div.stage: Enter JULIA, followed by TANGENT, carrying the Parcel—JULIA bows to CAUSTIC, in paſſing.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Zounds! my uncle!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Eh! what!—yes—no—it can't be!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well, my dear, have you made your purchaſes?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; the real black hyſon—ſweet, pretty article—defies the trade to ſell more cheaperer than us do—ma'am (bowing to Julia, and peeping at Cauſtic) oh—he knows me.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: 'Tis he, by all that's furious.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not quite ſo familiar, if you pleaſe, ſir. Well recollected—I want—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And I want—patience.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: We don't ſell it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Oh, you incorrigible—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, is it you? how do you do, uncle?—muſt brazen it out.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, ſir, what's that? (pointing to the apron) and what the devil are you at now?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Trade—commerce, uncle—ſoul of ſir Thomas Greſham—thou, who in the compting-houſe of the gods, ſitteſt—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Stop, ſtop, I ſay—have you forgot the woolſack?—think of the woolſack!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I do—wool is a ſtaple commodity. Commerce, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I ſay, law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The theory of commerce is abſtruſe, and very little understood.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Why, ſo is law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Commerce ſhews you what money will do.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: So does law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Commerce enriches the country.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: So does—no, no!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir, as father to this lady, I muſt demand an explanation of ſuch extraordinary conduct.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: With all my heart. Sir, your lovely daughter came to Allſpice's ſhop, when—I don't recollect how—but ſomehow or other, I had got this apron round me—ſhe took me for the ſhopman; and for the pleaſure of beholding her, I became a porter, and to continue that happineſs, wou'd become (ſeeing M' Query)—an attorney. This is the fact: I can't tell a lie for the ſoul of me.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Can't you? then I wou'd recommend you not to become an attorney.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Trade's the thing, uncle—underſtand it all—
I'll ſhip off a yard of ribbon with e'er a ſix-foot haberdaſher in town, return the drawer to it's place with a ſmack—roll up change in a bit of paper—ſmirk—preſent it with the counter-bow—an't I perfect, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Tangent! damnation!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I caſt you off, ſir, for ever! 'sdeath! were you my own child, your undutiful conduct wou'd be natural and excuſable. But you've no right to make me miſerable—I'm not your father, and I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And I inſiſt that my houſe may not be made the ſcene of your buffoonery.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, ſir, I—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And that you take leave of it, and that lady for ever.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh ſir, ſurely—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Girl!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: There—I'm glad on't. And now, ſir, you may think of the woolſack, ſir, or you may ſnip ribbons, ſir—or wrap up halfpence in whiteybrown paper ſir—I have' done with you, ſir—and there's the counter-bow for you, ſir. Captain Faulkner, good morning.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Captain Faulkner! then I may hear of my friend. Sir, tho' your conduct to me has been harſh, I flatter myſelf, unmeritedly ſo, yet my anxiety to hear
of a loſt friend induces me to ſolicit what I ſhou'd otherwis;e deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be brief, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Charles Richmond—Charles Richmond, ſir —is he no more?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: He fell by my ſide.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Poor Charles! I remember, when we were at college, we agreed, that whoever died batchelor, ſhou'd make the ſurvivor his heir; but he was too generous to be rich. Did he, ſir, leave any money?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not—not—that I—know of—agony!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, not that he knows of. I'll bring you off.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be dumb!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, he muſt have died poor; for villany itſelf could not wrong ſo noble a fellow.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Fiends! tortures!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Died poor, certainly. Do you ſuppoſe now, that if he had given any money to Mr. —

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Silence, dog!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Every dog has his day!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: With Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I'll not truſt you. Dare not for your life ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I may go home.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: This way then. Remember, I am no trifler. This way I ſay.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Madam, am I to conclude ſo trivial a levity could occaſion Captain Faulkner's behaviour, or—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, I am wholly ignorant (ſighs.). I never ſaw my father ſo before.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And may I hope, lovelieſt of women, that the ſentiments of that tender boſom—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, the ſentiment that governs here, is implicit obèdience to a father's will. He is returning. Pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: May I not hope, miſs Faulkner, that—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I beg, ſir—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Only—farewell!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How eccentric, yet how intereſting! what can my father mean?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Is he gone? thank heaven!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, has Mr. Tangent—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Do you combine to torture?—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my father, kill me, but do not ſrown on me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Kill thee, Julia.—Oh, I'm to blame.—But my mind is in agony.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: May I not ſhare it? may I not alleviate it?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, no.—We muſt leave this town to-day.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Thy father, Julia, is a beggar.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Worſe—He has contracted debts he cannot diſcharge, and muſt, like a raſcal, fly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Bear up, my heart!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, worſe — Thy father is — But why ſhould I agonize her more?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, don't deſpair.—We ſhall do very well. I can work, indeed I can—I am a ſtrong girl—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Revive, my child!—I ſhelter'd thee from miſery while it was poſſible.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is what your anceſtors left you, loſt, all loſt?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Yes, Julia, all— (aſide) for they left me honour.—But we muſt fly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Whither, my father?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Any where, to avoid—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I charge thee, name him not.—Go in.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my father, do not leave me—I, dread being alone.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I will but ruminate awhile, then come to thee.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But, preſently?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But, very ſoon?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Yes, my child:—go in.

Well, I lied it ſtoutly—the verieſt raſcal, that eats the bread of perjury, could not have lied it with more unbluſhing boldneſs. Where ſhall, I fly? the poor honeſt man, e'en in this knaviſh world, has ſome few friends, the rich villain more; but the poor raſcal— Ha! firſt a thief, and then a liar—what follows? ſome devil whiſpers, a ſelf-murderer. But oh! can I leave my girl to poverty, to ſcorn, to diſhonour?—No, no!
we part not. What remains?—To go to Tangent—crawl in the duſt, and be ſpurn'd by him!—rot and damn firſt!—deſpair then is only left: for the world's palliations, as degrees of guilt—the law of neceſſity will not give comfort here. No, to the truly proud, the firſt ſtep from honour is perdition.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father! you ſaid you'd come to me— don't be angry. Oh, do you ſmile on me? then Julia cannot be unhappy (embraces Faulkner). You frown'd juſt now—'twas the firſt time: indeed it cut my heart. Come, ſir, be chearful; for poverty cannot chill the conſcious glow of virtue, nor dim the celeſtial radiance of honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Lady Sorrel to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Deſire lady Sorrel to walk in. Exit ſervant, and re-enter with lady Sorrel. Your moſt obſequious, my lady. How am I to have the honour of ſerving you? Is it your will I'm to make?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: My will, ſir!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh what a blunder! Becauſe ladies often make their wills, when they ſhou'd be making their marriage articles.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: You gentlemen of the long robe flatter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You flatter, my lady! I of the long robe! No, I'm only, as I may ſay, a mere ſpencer of the law—Oh, how I love female clients! They are ſo eaſily pleas'd— (aſide) and ſo eaſily impoſed on.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p:
You are too polite. But that is the characteriſtic of Ireland—I've been there: and had I
remained, it is a country I ſhou'd have been tranſported with.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And had I remained there, it is a country I ſhou'd have been tranſported from.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, who poſſeſſes many amiable qualities—in my approbation of men, ſir, I always uſe discernment.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh you do— (aſide) For you always approve of young ones.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: He has fallen in love with a miſs Faulkner, whoſe father is, I hear, poor and proud. Pray, ſir, do you know any thing about him?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: A little: and one thing I know, is, that he owes me fifty pounds, and has not a ſhilling to pay me.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Indeed! If any thing cou'd prevent Tangent's attachment to the lady (a little witch) it wou'd certainly be for their good.—Does it ſtrike you how you cou'd be of ſervice to this captain and his fair daughter?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: What do you think of ſending them to —to—jail?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Jail! (aſide) Faith, that's one way of being of ſervice. Why, it's a good place for them to recollect themſelves in.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: And would prevent Tangent's ſeeing her.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And, bring down the pride of the father.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: And, as they are poor, wou'd contract their expenſes.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Apartment found them for nothing there, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Well, then, as captain Faulker owes you money, ſuppoſe you were to arreſt—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh I can't—I can't in honour, becauſe (aſide) I ſhou'd get nothing by it. Here is his bond. Now, many people take fancies to bonds—for my part, I'd juſt as ſoon have ready money—It's a mighty pretty bond; and if you purchaſe it, I'll ſend him to jail with all the pleaſure in life; for then, you know, I'm only an attorney in the buſineſs; and 'tis no matter what I do.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: How fortunate! Now I ſhall be revenged. Very well. Aſſign it to me; and, as we agree it will be for their good, you may as well arreſt—

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes; I'll give the captain a wholeſome tap on the ſhoulder. In the next room is parchment, pen, and ink.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I am going to Allſpice's gala. I ſuppoſe you will be there to pay your court to the barriſters?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No; I go there to have the barriſters pay court to me. You'll ſee the young ones crowd about me, like a plate full of potatoes round a butterboat, and try to wheedle me out of a light half guinea. Oh, miſs Faulkner is no more to be compared to you, madam, than a little twinkling ſtar is to the full moon.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, flattery's another characteriſtic of your country.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p:
My words exactly expreſs my meaning,
my lady; and that's another characteriſtic of my country.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A ſpacious ſuite of Rooms, brilliantly illiuminated,—muſic playing—card tables, &c.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What a horrid, capricious, old wretch that Mr. Cauſtic is! Juſt now, when, to humour him, I praiſed his nephew, he inſiſted I ſhould not name him. Well, I vow I'm glad of that; for Mr. Daſhall is far more toniſh. I obſerved him to-day, with his hands in his pockets, elbowing every body, treading on the ladies' toes, and without any apology, tearing their dreſſes in ſuch a ſtyle—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A gay thing, ma'am, faith—all elegance—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Except pa. Oh, ſir, did you hear him at dinner? He roſe up— (all the company were ſilent, expecting a complimentary addreſs) and roars out, "Ladies and gentlemen, pray don't ſpare the pickles, for there are plenty in the ſhop." Oh, I bluſhed in ſuch a ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Upon my ſoul—and all that— you're a fine creature! and intereſt my feelings more than any event, ſince Waxy, the race-horſe, won the Derby.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How flattering! How elegant! will you love me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: May virtue ſeize me, if, when we're married, I don't adore you!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Adore me!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes; that is, faſhionably.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: You would not have us found together debtor and creditor, in your father's ledger, or ſtuck together like his figs.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh! ſhocking!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No; ours ſhall be a ſtyliſh adoration—ſeparate beds—you making a daſh with your friend in one curricle; I making a ſplaſh with mine in another. You at Bath—I at Newmarket—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh charming! Hail, connubial love! Oh, here comes Mr. Cauſtic.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Then you ſhall ſee me hoax him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh no. It is he that has the diſpoſal of my aunt's fortune.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, that's the reaſon that all the women were paying court to him. I ſwear, he look'd like the grand ſignior with a ſeraglio at his heels.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But it all won't do. I am the favour'd ſultana.

div.stage: At the top of the ſtage, enter CAUSTIC bowing to a number of ladies about him, who paſs off.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
Ma'am, your moſt obedient—miſs, your devoted. Good-day, madam—oh, miſs, happy to ſee you. (coming forward) Oh my back! my back! I muſt go home, ha, ha! But I can't help laughing at
the abſurd adulation paid me. I who was yeſterday a ſour curmudgeon, am to-day the monopolizer of all human excellence. Oh my poor back! Oh world! world!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How do you do, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, you approve of our muſic and gala.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: To ſay the truth, madam, I preferr'd my own.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Your own, I vow! Pray, when did you give a gala, Mr. Cauſtic?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: In the laſt froſt, madam, to two hundred paupers and their helpleſs families—and we had our dancing too, ma'am: for the little chubby brats in merry anticks gambol'd round my knees: and we had muſic too, madam; for the widows ſung for joy.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Oh charming!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Damn'd fine indeed! I think with you certainly, ſir, that—what the devil is the word? Benevolence, is it not?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, there is ſuch a word—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye—benevolence, virtue, and all that, are at times extremely amuſing.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Amuſing! ſir, virtue is the buſineſs of our lives; all elſe is its idleneſs.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I vow, ſir, I was ſhocked to ſee you ſo teized by the fulſome attentions of the women. Flattery is not way to ſecure the approbation of a man—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Of your fine feelings and underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: It is not indeed! (aſide) Madam, Mr. Allſpice wants you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Favour me with your hand.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, your devoted. Ah, what worlds of feeling!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What oceans of ſenſe! (apart) I fancy we've tickled him in a capital ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Very neatly, too! ha, ha!
sp.stage: Exeunt ſmiling and nodding approbation to each other.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Theſe excite but laughter and contempt; but my vexatious nephew's tormenting.—But this I'm reſolved on,—if ever again he dare to—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Julia Faulkner! Julia Faulkner! By heaven, her beauty might ſet the world at war, and make another ſiege of Troy: and oh! were I general at that ſiege, I'd build caſtles—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Aye, that you wou'd!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What ſhou'd'oppoſe me? Sword in hand I'd ſtorm the breach— (puſhing between two chairs) I'd fire the palace, pull down the gates— (ſnatches up a chair) and ruſh into her arms, (is near embracing Cauſtic)—ah, uncle, is it you?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Keep off! How dare you approach me, you—are you not a pretty fellow?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So the ladies ſay, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And a fool?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So I ſay, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And a libertine?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: So you ſay, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And what do you ſay for yourſelf?—A profeſs'd libertine?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I ſay that I practiſe what I profeſs; which is more than you moraliſts can ſay.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Pſha! and the world ſays you're a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Damn the world then for making me one. How the devil can I help being a coxcomb, when I ſee a flattering fool like myſelf idolized, and modeſt worth deſpiſed? Uncle, the temple of Folly wou'd ſoon be without votaries, had it not the world for its worſhippers.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: But zounds! did the world clap you on the woolſack? did the world put you on an apron, or deſire you to make another ſiege of Troy?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I'm aſham'd of myſelf; but by future perſeverance and diligence, I'll atone for my follies. Come, uncle, forgive the paſt—ſhake hands.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: No—well—there—aye, Frank, perſevere, and you may ſoon convert your air-built caſtle into a ſolid one of brick and mortar.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: True; then every one will ſay, his character does not reſt on the flimſy baſis of hereditary worth, but on the noble exertion of talent.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: That's well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Then I with conſcious dignity will walk thro' my hall—my ſervants ranged on each ſide—I bend to them with eaſe, call my agent, and ſay to him, diſtribute an hundred pounds to—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Death and fury, you're at it again!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: No, no—that was only—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: What will drive me mad. 'Sdeath! what is talent without the will and means to exert it? 'Tis Newton without his teleſcope, or Handel without his organ.—Remember, this is your laſt, laſt warning!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: He's certainly right. That Handel was a great man; and tho' bereft of one ſenſe, how amply was another gratified! For what can ſtrike more gratefully on the heart, than hearing the honourable applauſe of an impartial public?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I'll juſt take a peep, and ſee the effect my lecture has had.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tho' Handel was blind, how I envy him his ſenſations, when, ſeated before an enraptured audience, he thus began, and charmed all hearts— (ſhuts his eyes and plays on the table) Oh, charming! bravo!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: You villain! if ever I ſpeak to you again, may I—I diſcard you for ever—for ever—and for ever!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, confound this crack'd head! What a ſcrape have I got into.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
So, here's the wife he intends for me. Marry
her, and doat on Julia. Sweet ſituation mine wou'd be! I can very well fancy myſelf—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Brute! ſir, my pa wiſhes to ſpeak—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll come to your pa. (ruminating, and not looking at her) No, Julia, I'll be only thine—I'll come to your pa.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: This way, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll come to your pa—I'll be only thine, my Julia—I'll come to your pa—
sp.stage: (follows Clementina to one ſide of the ſtage, and walks cut abſorb'd in thought at the oppoſite ſide

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gone! Well, this is certainly beyond all the fine breeding I ever ſaw—Miſs Faulkner?

div.stage: Enter JULIA, in great agitation, her hair diſorder'd.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, madam, forgive this intruſion—you told me you had a friendſhip for me. Oh, ſhow it now! my father is arreſted—in a dreadful ſituation.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: So are you, my dear, in a dreadful ſituation. Never kneel in a public room.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Madam, I ſaid my dear father,—the beloved author of my being, is in a priſon.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Well! we're ruined, madam.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: That's certainly extremely diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Oh, my dear, don't mind It—arreſted! Nothing can be more faſhionable. I dare ſay all will be well. Good bye! I'm ſorry I can't aſſiſt you but the
guinea loo-table waits for me. Pray come and ſee me when your affairs are ſettled. Good bye, my dear! Good bye! Good bye!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This, in proſperity, was my warmeſt friend. Alas! ſuch friends are as the leaves that clothe the tree in the genial ſummer, but leave it naked to the winter's blaſt. Whither ſhall I go? Heavens! Mr. Tangent!

div.p: Sir—hold! did not my father forbid my ſpeaking to him? But is not that father in want?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Married to a woman I diſlike.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Married! Oh, my heart! Julia, this is no time for thy ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! if I'm miſerable, what ſignifies my having thouſands in my pocket's?—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How fortunate!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Marry for thirty thouſand! Pſha! (takes box) With decent luck I'd win it in ten minutes.—Did you ſay, ſir, you'd ſet me 500l.—done! Seven's the main, and ſix I have—off in two throws a thouſand—done—ſix it is! Bravo! Come, gentlemen, a thouſand each if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Mr. Tangent, I want—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Double or quit? you ſhall have it (turning round.)—Heavens! miſs Faulkner! damn this head of mine—it's in ſuch a whirl.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, pity and relieve!

div.stage: Enter DASHALL at the back Scene.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What's here? fine girl, faith!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I know my behaviour is wild, is imprudent, but my excuſe is, a father in priſon and broken hearted—ſave but him.—For myſelf I care not.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: By heaven ſhe puts herſelf in my power, and what an exquiſite temptation! here's an opportunity to eſtabliſh my character as a man of gallantry! hold! here's an opportunity to eſtabliſh my reputation as a man of honour. The father of my love in priſon, and I without change for ſixpence—I'll go this inſtant and borrow money at 500 percent.—I'll—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I'm ſure you'll relieve me—I'm ſure you have a generous heart. The debt is but fifty pounds. I heard you ſay had thouſands in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ma'am, I ſaid—that—I—that is I—Oh! curſe this crack'd head! but I'll get the money inſtanly. Miſs Faulkner, it is with ſhame and confuſion I declare, that at this moment it is not in my power to be of the leaſt aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? is this the man to whom I've given my heart?—'tis too much (is near fainting, when Daſhall runs to her aſſiſtance) ah! a ſtranger!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Don't be alarmed, young lady— (aſide) I ſee I muſt give her a touch of the ſober citizen. Madam, I heard your diſtreſs; I am inquiſitive after ſorrow— I poſſeſs a large fortune, 'tis true; but only in truſt for the worthy who want it. A ſober, plodding citizen,
as you ſee, plain in my manners, plainer in my dreſs—deſpiſe powder and embroidery—a mere London merchant!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The world knows their benevolence.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Pretty well. But you muſt not ſuppoſe all London merchants like me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Will you, ſir—will you, then, ſave my father? I can't expreſſs what I feel.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: That's very odd! when I can ſo well expreſs what I do not feel. Madam, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I'll expect you at the priſon where my father is.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, no!—I can't tell you why; but I have a ſtrange antipathy to priſons. But in two hours time at the gate of it, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, I'll bleſs you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Upon my foul I mean it. Now I ſuppoſe I ſhou'd ſay gallant things, but I cannot. Suffice it, I will be there.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewell!—happy, happy Julia!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I will be there ready— Exit Julia. with a poſt-chaiſe and four to carry you off, my nice one—then chevy, away for the next town—confine her—ſwear ſhe's a runaway wife—return—marry miſs Allſpice—do old Toby out of the ready. Ha, ha! here he comes—what a gig it is!

div.stage: Enter ALLSPICE, his hair cropt, a full-dreſs coat on, ſinging—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Well, here I am—as gay a daſher as the beſt of you—ſnug about the head, eh?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But what a quiz of a coat you've on!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Don't you like it? it was my grandfather's.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Your dinner was ſtyliſh, faith.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Very; but it had one little fault. There was nothing to eat—grottoes, trees, fountains, ſweetmeat ſhepherdeſſes, and buttered Cupids in plenty,—nothing elſe. I ſhou'd have been half ſtarved, had I not luckily looked over my ſhoulder, and there beheld my old friend, the honoured ſirloin, on the ſideboard—I could have cried to ſee him ſo diſgraced; but I order'd him to be conducted to the top of the table, and the muſic to ſtrike up "Oh the Roaſt Beef of Old England!" and, then, how I ogled the girls, and how they titter'd at me! women give a man's ideas ſo elegant a turn. I'm as much above what I was, as a hogſhead is to a butter firkin.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Butter firkin! curſe it, and ſink it, Toby, talk like a gentleman. But, I ſay, you ſeem a little damaged.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes; funny, an't I? I got hold of a little bottle, ſuch as they put ketchup in—by the bye I can ſell you ſome very fine ketchup, if you want any—It was deviliſh good, yoyeo they call it.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yoyeo! pſha! noyau.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Well, well, noyau. Egad, when I found it coſt a guinea, and that I was to pay for it—I drank it all every drop.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A guinea! bagatelle! I'll put you in a way to drink it every day.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: How, my dear friend:?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I've had a letter from my clerk.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Your hunting clerk?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes; he has a ſcheme of buying up furs, by which 100 per cent. muſt be made in a month.—A trifle—five thouſand—will do; but at preſent my caſh is here and there. Indeed at this moment I can't exactly tell you where it is, But if you ſhould like it—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
