sp.p: You would not have me lay out five thouſand pounds in muffs and tippets, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Five thouſand! I've ſpeculated deeper in darning needles.—But you have not the caſh?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes but I have tho'—that ſum in the houſe. too—I intended to buy with it half an eſtate valued at ten thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Then defer the purchaſe one month, and I'll engage you ſhall buy the whole.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh charming! ah, but ſhould it fail—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But it can't fail—if it do, then blame me.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: That's enough.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: All you will have to do, will be to come to town in a month, and hug your ten thouſand pounds, as ſure as the ſweet Harriet will hug you.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p:
Oh the pretty one! That has fixed me. When the company is gone, I'll give you bank notes to the amount:—and tell your hunting clerk, if he'll make the five thouſand ten, I'll give him a guinea. Oh, what a rich, jolly dog I ſhall be! let's go and have another touch at the little bottle,—another guinea's worth—damn the expence! and drink confuſion to
retailing, and Harriet's health in a bumper! "Lovely Nymph," &c.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If this is'nt doing it, the devil's in it, ha, ha! I've bother'd the daughter, and tickled old Cauſtic in a capital ſtyle,—that's a dead thirty thouſand.—Humbugged the old one here out of five, and ſhall carry off the nice girl to a certainty. What a ſplaſh I ſhall make along Cheapſide! what a ſwagger I ſhall cut at Lloyd's! how the city bucks will ſtare, and, may be, dreſs at me. And then we ſhall have Birmingham Daſhalls as well as Birmingham Dukes. Oh, I'm a neat article!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Come, come, the money—quick!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You'll pay deviliſh dear for it.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! that's my affair.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You muſt give your bond for five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What caſh am I to touch?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Two. I can't afford more on my honour.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: My honour? yes, honour is the conſervation of ſociety—(Oh, I'wiſh I cou'd recollect Captain Faulkner's flaſhy ſpeech)—Honour! is—upon my ſoul I can't tell what honour is.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I believe you. But you mention'd Captain Faulkner's name.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Yes. Oh, I could ſell you a nice ſecret about him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell me a ſecret, did you ſay.?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No—I ſaid, ſell you a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Well, I am a buyer—any thing reſpecting him is intereſting.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: And you may get a thouſand pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Make your own terms.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Faulkner has humm'd you out of that ſum.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Your friend, Charles Richmond, left it to you, and the old ſly thief ſmuſhed it. He told a palavering ſtory about diſtreſſes, and his dear daughter, and his wife's funeral, and a parcel of balderdaſh.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Poor Faulkner! my heart bleeds for him. This explains his behaviour.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Then he has had a law-ſuit; but he's non-ſuited, as this letter will ſhew you

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Come, ſir, draw the bond, (looks at the letter)—What's this? (reads) I remit you your ſhare of the bribe for the error in Faulkner's declaration;—have alſo received, under his power of attorney, two thouſand pounds prize-money. Scoundrels! Which is much better in our hands than his.—The more we diſtreſs him, the leſs danger there is of detection.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You ſee by that letter how things are, and what care I've taken of the Captain's property.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll put this in my pocket, and read it at leiſure.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No, no—I'm always for vouchers—that letter ſhou'd not be loſt.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: There I agree with you. Eh, I have it— (Tears off the half ſheet with the contents of the letter, from the half ſheet that, contains the addreſs, wraps that up, and gives it to M'Query.) So—there's the letter.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Let me ſee (looking at it)—Now—that's as it ſhould be

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Exactly—Is the bond ready?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Aye, ſign away.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: But we have no witneſs.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh! I've a clerk will ſet his hand to it at any time—That Faulkner's a pretty fellow, is'nt he? To be ſure, the coolneſs with which ſome people take others' property is amazing (taking up the bond)—In two hours' time you ſhall have the two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very well; I muſt go, and tickle my old uncle, and then away to relieve poor Faulkner.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: You've got the money very dear.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe. The ſenſation I feel at this moment is cheap at ten times the ſum.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Rather a neat morning's work.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Tangent?

sp.speaker: M'query
sp.p: This moment gone.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I hear the fool's in love with a miſs Faulkner,—a female fortune-hunter, I ſuppoſe. Aye, like her fex—ſharp as a razor.—You've found them ſo, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Oh yes; and, like a razor, I've found ſtrapping a mighty good thing for them.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And does he think I'll forgive this?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: He does. He ſays he'll tickle you.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Tickle me, will he'? we'll ſee that. Except in the article of money; there, indeed, he has reformed. Thank heaven, he don't borrow thouſand of you now.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: No—he only borrows five hundreds.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Eh! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: There's his bond, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I'm petrified!

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: I'll ſell it you.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Sell it me! he owes me thouſands—a profligate! I ſhall be ruined—a beggar! but I'll humble him. He knows the way to tickle me, you know—now we'll ſee—arreſt him—I'll ſhew him I can tickle him—I order you, ſir, to arreſt him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: With all my heart and foul.—You will make the affidavit, and I will touch him up with a bit of a capias.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Aye, a capias. I'll humble him.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: Then follow that up widi a fi—fa.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Aye, a fi—fa.

sp.speaker: M'Query.
sp.p: If that won't do, tip him a ca—fa.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Aye, tip him a ca—fa. He can tickle me, can he? a profligate! come along!

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: The chaiſe is ready, your honour.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Capital horſes, eh?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: Like myſelf—blood every inch.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Snug, you dog.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: Oh, as ſharp as my ſpurs.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How ſurpriſed the girl will be, ha, ha! curſe me if I can help laughing to think how ſhe'll cry, ha, ha!
Bailiffs, by all that's—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ah, maſter Daſhall, how are you?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How do you do, Ned? how do you do?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You need not be afraid.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Afraid! no to be ſure, I know that.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We don't want you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Eh, don't you tho'?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Honour!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, honour

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Honour among thieves.

sp.speaker: Daſh
sp.p: By the Lord you frighten'd me.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We are not bailiffs now—we're in the mad line.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Mad line!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: We belong to Dr. Coercion, and are come after a patient that has eſcaped—a mad lawyer.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Mad lawyer! I always thought it was the client who was out of his ſenſes. Well, good bye, Ned. 'Sdeath! here comes Tangent, perhaps to relieve Faulkner: and then I loſe the girl—Eh, it would be knowing, he, he! here goes! ſo, Ned, you're come here after a mad lawyer.—Do you know his perſon?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I do, intimately; and, by heaven, here he comes! that's he—don't he look as if he was mad?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Oh, a clear caſe—now, this is ſo kind of you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: You'll take care of the poor fellow—ecod, Ned, you frighten'd me. Be ſure now you take care of the poor devil, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Tom, mind your hits.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now to poor Faulkner's priſon, and reſtore happineſs to my Julia!—Julia! if I don't watch this addle-head of mine, I ſhall certainly go mad. There's ſomething ſublime in madneſs! rolling eye—dungeons—ſtraw—chains—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Come, come, that will do—a pretty dsnce you've led us.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Who are you, and what do you want with me?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Tom, have you a ſtrait waiſtcoat in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Strait waiſtcoat! what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Take you back to the mad doctor's.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Be quiet, you ſcoundrels!

div.stage: Enter SERVANT to CAUSTIC, and BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: That's he you are to arreſt. Touch him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh, here's Cauſtic's ſervant. Come here, ſir—am I mad, ſir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mad, ſir? no, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tell theſe raſcals who I am.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Oh, this is Mr. Tangent.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Aye, Frank Tangent's my name, is not it?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: That it is.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You're an honeſt fellow!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Then you ſhall go with an honeſt fellow—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A writ! oh! the devil! worſe and worſe! at whoſe ſuit?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic's.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Pretty way I'm in! arreſted at this moment! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Pay a viſit to my lock-up-houſe.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I can't—'pon my honour I'm engaged—eh, I believe I'd better be mad (to Cauſtic's ſervant) ah! kneel down before your father and mother.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I'm your father and mother. I'm father and
mother of all the judges—vanity's father and mother of all the counſellors—the devil's father and mother of all the bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He's mad.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Fudge! that's not madneſs.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I am mad, you ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I ſay he is mad.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: I ſay he an't mad

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I'll be off—ha! I ſpy a brother.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Mad or not, we muſt not loſe him: ſo, come along.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Aye, aye; we muſt have him.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: By this time he's ſafe. I think I've given him a tickler, (noiſe) What! he reſiſts, does he? (Reenter a ſervant) Well, ſir, have they got him?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, ſir: but he fought them nobly; then I came up.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And ſecured the raſcal?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, your honour: I don't know how it was; but ſeeing three upon him, ecod, I coudn't help, ſomehow, fighting on his ſide; ſo I knock'd one down, and he killed another.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: What do you ſay? killed a man!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There he lies, bleeding like a pig.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Has my poor Frank been ſo raſh? I hope he eſcaped.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No; they got hold of him.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I'm a miſerable man—This is all my fault.
Is the man dead? oh, my poor boy!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: No, your honour; the cowardly chap ſwooned at the ſight of his blood.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Then the raſcal has not killed him, eh?

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: A guinea and a plaiſter will ſet all right.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Will it? he kill a man! what an old fool I was! hold, I have it. Let the man be conveyed to my houſe—give out his life's in danger. I'll have him taken up for a murderer: I'll lay him with the duſt. Away with him to priſon—I'll be ſo revenged! and, d'ye hear: put irons on him; (going) but don't ſtarve him—give him bread and water, (going) and, d'ye hear, give him ſtraw—give him plenty of ſtraw.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: FAULKNER diſcovered, JULIA leaning on him.—A noiſe without of chains falling. JULIA ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Be not alarmed. Theſe noiſes, Julia, we ſhall be accuſtom'd to.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I hope not, my father. It is the hour I promiſed to be at the priſon gate. (Faulkner ſhakes his head) The gentleman ſeemed a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
And, perhaps, is called ſo. Ah, girl, the tickery of this knaviſh world makes a wide difference between honour to woman and to man. The wretch that robs the father of his child, let him but at a gaming table keep his word with man, and he's of honour
Nay, ſhou'd this wretch, in aggravation, meet that wrong'd father in the field, and lay him at his feet a corpſe, then, who dare deny that he's a man of honour?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But he's a merchant, ſir—a rank of men whoſe nobleneſs and benevolence are far above my praiſe.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: True; let me not by vague ſuſpicion wrong a worthy man. Go then, my child, but only to the gate; and mark, return with ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Shall I not fly, when 'tis to bring a father happineſs?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: And ſhould it not be ſo, oh Faulkner, what horrors will be thine! when, in addition to thy wounded pride, thou heareſt thy child aſk thee for bread thou can'ſt not give her, ſee'ſt her pine daily at thy feet and periſh; or, what is worſe, ſhould the agony which rends this heart, draw on thee a ſpeedier diſſolution, and ſhe be left behind, expoſed to want, to villany—that ſhall be prevented! yet I'll cling to hope—perhaps all may be well again— (Julia ſcreams without) ah! ſhe ſhrieks! It is my Julia's voice. Villain, forbear! hear a father's cries, or take a father's curſe. Blaſt him, heaven, with thy hotteſt vengeance! all, all is huſhed—ſhe's gone! my child is loſt, is diſhonoured—diſhonoured! no, I wrong her—my girl will die— (a noiſe again) It approaches—be faithful, eyes!
sp.stage: Enter JAILER and TANGENT, he bearing JULIA in his arms.
sp.p: My Julia! oh give her to my arms!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, after what has paſſed, ſome excuſe is due for this intruſion. There, ſir, is my apology.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: She revives!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Where am I? my father! my deliverer!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Aye, that he is—As this gentleman was coming to jail—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Huſh! (ſtopping his mouth) Paſſing this place, ſir, I heard a woman ſhriek, and ſaw ſome villains hurry this lady into a chaiſe—

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Then he bravely flew among them, and laid about him, and—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: The conqueſt was eaſy, for the raſcals fled.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Saved by the man I've ſo deeply wrong'd! His preſence tortures me. Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner, a word in private.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah! am I detected?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I've been with your attorney, ſir.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Racks! tortures!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And have diſcovered an infernal act of villany.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well then, it is diſcovered.—Madneſs! fiends! I wou'd be alone.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You miſtake.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I inſiſt on being alone.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A meſſage from your attorney, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis well—Captain Faulkner, you will be ſorry for this behaviour.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
My brain rocks! ah, my child, do I hold
thee in a parent's graſp, pure, unpolluted? Julia, we part no more—never—never! 'tis time to tell thee thy father is a villain.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Impoſſible! perhaps your too keen ſenſe of honour interprets harſhly.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: No, no. E'en now the man I wrong'd gave it its ſubſtantial title—an infernal act of villany.—Horrors accumulate.—On one ſide, diſhonour; on the other, famine. Julia! (taking both her hands, and looking on her) tho' dreadful, it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Your words and looks terrify me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In this world we can cheriſh no hope of happineſs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But in the next, my father—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: True, girl; then the ſooner we are there, the better.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Tis in our power, Julia, to expedite our happineſs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What means my father?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, heart-ſtrings, hold awhile! collect the exalted reſolution of thy ſoul, and mark. Out of the wreck of fortune, I have preſerved ſomething, my child, to free us from poverty, from diſhonour, and to give us everlaſting peace.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Bleſt tidings!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Behold!
sp.stage: (taking from each pocket a piſtol, and preſenting one to Julia.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Horror!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ha! haſt thou not by miracle eſcaped diſhonour? and is not thus to live, to meet perdition?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Is not thus to die, to meet perdition?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: It is too late for thought. Here—Ah, doſt thou ſhirk?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Suicide! my ſoul ſickens at the thought.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then live, baſe girl, and ſee thy father die. Live till ſcorn ſhall point at thee, and, mocking, cry, behold the violated daughter of the villain Faulkner!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There's madneſs in the thought—give me the deathful inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Hold! oh let me kiſs thee— (a knocking at the door) we're interrupted— (knocking repeated) go to the door
sp.stage: (Julia goes to the door, returns with a letter, opens it, ſhrieks, and runs into her father's arms.)
sp.p: What means this frantic joy? bank notes! a letter! ah, from Tangent— (reads) While I intreat you will do me the honour of employing theſe notes, it gives me great pleaſure to incloſe you a letter, which at once expoſes the villany of your agents, and reſtores you to proſperity and happineſs— (looks over the letter, then falls on his knee) omnipotent providence! humbled with the duſt, behold a repentant wretch! but thou art ſlow to puniſh, and thy mercies are infinite. Here, too, let me aſk pardon—my child! —But where is thy deliverer, the preſerver of thy honour, thy life? Within—Has Mr. Tangent left the priſon?

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Oh, no, ſir.—Then they don't know that he's a priſoner.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Then fly to him, my child. He is the legitimate ſon of honour, I the baſe born ſlave of pride. Bring him to me, that I may kneel and bleſs him.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father—I'm dizzy with my happineſs. One kiſs of rapture, and I am gone.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter JAILER, followed by TANGENT, (fetter'd) a Solicitor and Undertaker.

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: Oh, how they become him! I'm ſure your leg was made for them. I'll be hanged if I flatter you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Indeed you do not. Certainly, a very neat appendage to a gentleman—heigho!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: I declare it gives me pleaſure to ſee you in them.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You have all the pleaſure to yourſelf. Heigho! I feel deviliſh queer. Retire!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: A card from the gentlemen of our club.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your club! (reads) The gentlemen priſoners inform Mr. Tangent they have elected him a member of the ſelect club, and ſolicit the honour of his company to a turbot, haunch, claret, and chicken hazard.—The club, to prevent accidents, meet on Sunday, Monday being hanging-day. Hanging-day!—'tis alarming, very,—what do you want?—

sp.speaker: Solicitor.
sp.p: I'm a Newgate ſolicitor; and for 501. will undertake to prevent gibbeting at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Gibbeting! Begone, you croaking— (drives, him off) And what will you undertake?

sp.speaker: Undertaker.
sp.p: Sir, I'm an undertaker; and if you, are not engaged, wou'd be proud to inter—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Go to the devil! (drives him off) Leave the room, you infernal—Gibbet! Undertaker!—Heigho! —Pugh! I can't have kill'd the fellow—his ſcull muſt have been thinner than mine, to crack with ſuch a paltry blow.—How has my letter ſped with Faulkner —That's neareſt my heart—Oh, Julia!

sp.speaker: Jailer.
sp.p: You'll find Mr. Tangent in the next room, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Heavens! 'tis Julia! 'tis herſelf! and joy brightens her lovely countenance. Oh, let me meet her! Damn theſe things! 'Sdeath! how ſhall I conceal my diſgrace? What can I do to—

div.stage: (Tangent holds his handkerchief before his fetters).

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, with a heart oppreſs'd with gratitude, let me kneel—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Lovelieſt creature, riſe! Allow me to— (is about to raiſe her when he recollects his fetters) Pray riſe, ma'am; you diſtreſs me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Why ſhould benevolence ſhrink from praiſe?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Angelic excellence! call it love, adoration— I'm your ſlave—upon my ſoul, I'm in chains—I beg pardon—but my love is pure as your own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Sir, I believe you noble—above baſe concealment.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: By heaven I would not conceal any thing; that is, not any thing that—that—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, my father is anxious to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Happy tidings!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Will you favour him with your company?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This way then.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. (recollecting himſelf) That is, preſently—I'll come preſently to—to—to his houſe.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewel! Oh, ſir, my feelings wou'd be unworthy, cou'd I expreſs them—But theſe tears of joy—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dry them, lovely creature. By heaven, they affect me to that—
sp.stage: (raiſes his handkerchief to his eyes, recollects himſelf, then pulls a chair towards him, and gets behind it, leans over it, and wipes his eyes.)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: What noiſe was that?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I did not hear any noiſe.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The clank of fetters. I dread to meet thoſe miſerable beings—Perhaps ſome horrid murderer.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Very likely, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yet I muſt pity them.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis very kind of you, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Poor wretches!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Ah, poor devils!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Farewel, ſir. We ſhall ſee you ſoon.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
I'II follow you and fly—Egad, that's the only way I can follow. Heigho! But away with
melancholy. Julia Faulkner is happy; and can I be otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: There he ſits, the picture of deſpair, poor fellow! This leſſon has cured him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Theſe decorations are not exactly the thing, to be ſure, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: How mournfully he looks down on his diſgraceful fetters!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Julia is happy—The thought is extacy!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: How lucky that I came! His deſpair might have made him kill himſelf.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I could ſing—dance for joy. Dance! I remember ſeeing a man at the playhouſe dance a hornpipe in a pair of theſe things, and did it deviliſh well too—Let me ſee—ſomehow!—Tol de rol lol lol! (ſings and dances, not ſeeing Cauſtic) My uncle! Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Cauſtic.
sp.p: I ſhall go mad! (after a ſtruggle for brea •• ) Oh you—I can't ſpeak—dancing! But you'll have but one dance more, and that will be upon nothing, —you—the wounded man is dead.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Dead! Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Moſt certain, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Am I then a murderer? Shall I never ſee Julia Faulkner more?

div.stage: Enter NED (with a patch on his forehead) and JAILER.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt go home;—ſo, will thank you for the five guineas you promiſed.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Go along, you ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Never to behold—Eh! (ſeeing Ned) Oh, my dear fellow, how glad I am to ſee you! (embraces him) Here, take off theſe things, will you? (Ned and Jailer take off the fetters) I thought ſuch a head as this cou'd not be eaſily crack'd, ha, ha, ha! (exulting) Now to my Julia! Farewel, uncle! Here's caſh for you both.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Then I muſt kill the dog myſelf. (graſps his cane) Nephew, come here—will you only liſten to me?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I'll liſten to you for a month.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I'll murder him—ſtop that villain.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter DASHALL with an opened letter.

sp.speaker: Daſhall.
sp.p: Now this is not fair play! What a raſcally ſhame! What the devil does Fortune mean by it? Zounds! to be bankrupt! My name in the Gazette at this moment, when I was doing them all in ſuch a capital ſtyle! And, then, to loſe the nice girl! I ſuppoſe I ſhall have that fellow, Tangent, demanding ſatisfaction. Oh, my ſmaſhing will fly about like wildfire. If I can't in one hour humbug old Allſpice, and marry his daughter, I muſt ſcud. Fortune, be but kind! Damn her! ſhe's a jade, I'll not invoke her. But thou, genius of ſwindling! Oh ſtick by me now, and I'll never forſake thee. She's propitious! for here comes one flat.
Well, Toby, what are you thinking about?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p:
London. I never was there. You muſt ſhow me the ſights—The lions at the Tower, and the bulls and bears at the Stock Exchange; the parliament-houſe, and the wax-work;—the bench of biſhops, and
the maids of honour. And, my dear friend, you'll ſhow me the King's Bench?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Aye, that I will.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: And, I ſay, the pretty girls.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: True, my dear fellow: but about the trifle of money—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Trifle! Oh, the half-crown that I loſt to you at all-fours.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, no; the five thouſand.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh dear, that's an enormous ſum.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: My letters from Peterſburgh ſay, the froſt has ſet in there ſo deviliſh hard, that furs will be any price.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Indeed! I have the money in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Have you? Give it me directly.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Friendly creature, how anxious you are!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I am. Upon my ſoul, I feel juſt as if I were going to receive it for my own advantage.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Good ſoul! Well, here it is.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Now I touch.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, ſir, wiſhes to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Very well. I'll come to him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Confound Mr. Cauſtic! My bankruptcy will be blown, and then—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Tho' 'tis for my own advantage, I can't bear to part with my dear notes.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If I have not the money directly, 'tis all up, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: That would be a pity.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: It wou'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Why, then, there they are—but let me take leave of them—my pretty ones, good bye to you; and be ſure now you come again, with each of you a companion. One hug, and then we part.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Now I touch to a certainty.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Now hold our hand.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: The Gazette, ſir.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh the devil!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Stop!
sp.stage: (returns the notes again to his pocket)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Never mind the Gazette.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: We'll juſt take a peep at the bankrupts.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Here's luck again!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ah! (taking out his glaſſes) Here they are.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But don't you ſee there's great news. The following diſpatch was this day received by—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: We'll read that afterwards.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: "Whereas a commiſſion of—"

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Why, friend Toby, ha, ha, ha!
sp.stage: (taking hold of the arm that holds the Gazette)

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What's the matter?—"Whereas a—"

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha! What the devil! 'Tis all up with you—can't you ſee without ſpectacles? Ha, ha! Oh, then you are diſhed with the girls, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p:
See without them? to be ſure I can—juſt as
well without them, as with them. Bleſs your ſoul! I only uſe them, becauſe they are knowing.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes, knowing enough for young men with remarkable ſtrong eyes; but—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: "Whereas—"

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And then ſuch a quiz of a pair as theſe! How you wou'd be hoaxed! Now, only ſee what a gig I look in them.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Firſt we'll juſt look at the bankruptſ— "Whereaſ—"

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, no—now ſee. (takes the glaſſes and Gazette from Allſpice, letſ fall the glaſſes, and in pretending to pick them up, treads on them, and breaks them) Zounds! I've broke them.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: 'Tis of no conſequence—they were of no uſe to me—Thank heaven, I don't want them.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But I beg ten thouſand pardons. I believe you wiſhed to look over the liſt of bankrupts—there they begin, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh yes, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Any body there particular? Any body there you know?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, no, no—a few reptiles of retailers, but none of your fine daſhers like us—Ah! they manage their matters too cleverly to let me ſee them here.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To be ſure they do. (takes the Gazette) There I am, ſure enough—what an eſcape! Well, now the notes—now I touch, or the devil's in't!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes, here they are. (takes notes out again) Stop—one—two—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Three— ••• r—five. Juſt the ſum.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh dear. I don't like to part with them! My dear friend, I'm afraid I've given you a thouſand ſhort—Let me look at them again, will you?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Certainly. No—exactly the ſum.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, ſir, is in a great hurry and in a great paſſion, and wants to ſpeak to you about miſs Clementina, and that gentleman's marriage.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ha, ha! here's capital luck! Go to him, my dear Toby—let it take place directly. Tell him my affairs are deſperate,—my love affairs, I mean.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Well, I will — I'll ſay you're a bankrupt in hope. But don't ſend away all the money to London at once, pray don't.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Certainly not—depend on't, if I can help it, I'll not part with a farthing of it.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, thank you—'Tis an enormous ſum—I don't know what to think.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What to think! Think of the profits. Nay, why ſo dull? Where's your ſpirits, your life?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: My life! You've got it in your pocket, ſo pray take care of it; for, indeed, the loſs of it wou'd kill me.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Here they are! Oh, there goes lady Sorrel in a fury. I think ſhe looks as if ſhe were in the Gazette— I muſt be after her—Well, I've done the old one, however. Bravo, my boy, Daſhall! All I ſay is, you've juſtified the opinion I always had of you.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: How provoking! I cou'd cry for vexation. Where is that fellow, Daſhall, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: So, ſir, you've managed matters finely!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I rather think I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Provoking! to have that gypſey, that Julia Faulkner in your power, and then to loſe her!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I believe you could not help running away.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Nonſenſe! Will your talking recover her?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Yes, if you'll attend to it. I have a plan, if you are not afraid of her—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Dam'me! Do you think I'm afraid of a woman?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: That villain, Tangent, has releaſed her father from priſon: but I've a ſcheme—ſtay, he's here.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Then I would rather not ſtay; He's a deſperate fighting fellow! (aſide) I ſay, ſtep in here till he paſſes.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: What! running away again?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
'Sdeath! no. But my affairs are deviliſh tickliſh. I have not time to quarrel and kill people.
Here he comes: If you don't go in, I'll give up Julia. Can't you tell me your plan there as well as here?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: But if we ſhould be ſeen,—and my couſin Cauſtic hear I was ſhut up with a man, I ſhou'd be ruined.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Nobody wants to ruin you. Zounds! only while he paſſes.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
That infernal hornpipe has completely ruin'd me with my uncle. But, be that as it may, if ſhe will conſent, Julia Faulkner ſhall be mine, tho' this ſpade were my only portion. And why not this ſpade? What can more nobly employ the exertion of man than improving the bleſſings providence has ſent him? I can fancy myſelf ſeated at my cottage-fire, with my Julia and thirteen children,—the equal ſerenity of the ſcene harmonizing with the tranquil uniformity of my diſpoſition. Happy employment! There we ſee the art of man even giving climate. (pointing to the hot-houſe) Eh! I thought I caught a glimpſe of that hypocrite, lady Sorrel, endeavouring to conceal herſelf. I ſuppoſe a hot-houſe ſuits the warmth of her diſpoſition; if ſo, ſhe ſhall have it hot enough.— (aloud) Confound the careleſsneſs of theſe raſcally gardeners, leaving doors and windows open!—cold as an ice-houſe. (locks door) The grapes will be ſour; and I know there's a fine old ſenſitive plant within, that can't bear being expoſed—I'll bring things forward, (during this he puts up the glaſs, opens the flues, and blows the fire) Zounds! My
uncle, and as furious as when I left him!—I muſt be off—I preſume your ladyſhip begins to feel rather warm and comfortable.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Come, ſir, diſpatch—Let me get rid of this buſineſs. Where's this Daſhall and your daughter? I muſt be gone—I would not ſtay in this infernal town—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: True; there's no making a ſplaſh here. I muſt reſide in a place ſuited to my elegant ideas. London's the ſhop for me.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: But, zounds! where's your daughter?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: How kind of you to regard my Cleme!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I regard her! Sir, ſhe's a lady I particularly diſlike. Do you think I give her thirty thouſand pounds becauſe—No, ſir, I do it to revenge myſelf on that thoughtleſs, profligate, tormenting nephew, that has teized, has made me mad—but where is ſhe?—Oh, ſhe comes—heyday! what, in tears?

div.stage: Enter CLEMENTINA, weeping, holding a Gazette in her hand; and Officer.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What's the matter, Cleme?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Now this is extremely diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What makes my dear daughter unhappy? Nothing ſerious, I hope. None of the ſpoons loſt, eh?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Spoons? Don't talk to me of ſpoons. My fortune is loſt, my huſband is loſt—this man is come to take him away. Mr. Daſhall is a bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: His name in the Gazette.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Where? where? Oh, will any body lend me a pair of ſpectacles?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Are you ſhort-ſighted?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh very—I've a notion.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ah! (pointing to his name in the Gazette) There he is.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Where is he? (jumping round and ſeizing Cauſtic) He's a villain!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I thought he was your friend,—the man that cropt you.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes, he has cropp'd me with the devil to it; cropped me of five thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Five thouſand pounds! What was he to do with it?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: To buy tippets.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Tippets!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Ay, and boſom-friends. What had I to do with boſom-friends? Damn all friends! I was once happy and friendleſs. Eh! I left him here. I hope he is not gone to make a ſplaſh with my dear money—I hope he's in the garden. Mr. Daſhall! Mr. Daſhall! I want to ſpeak to you, Mr. Daſhall. Come here, will you, my dear friend? I only want to ſpeak to you. Oh, if I cou'd but faſten on him—I want to give you another thousand pounds. I do indeed. Oh, the infernal villain! My excellent friend, don't hide yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Everlaſting, everlaſting diſappointment! will nobody have thirty thouſand pounds?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, pray ſir, don't be in ſuch a hurry. If you will but have the kindneſs to wait till to-morrow, I dare ſay I can get ſomebody to marry me.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I would not ſtay an hour. Will nobody have thirty thouſand pounds?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: I will, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: But on the terms—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Any terms.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Will you marry?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Any body.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You marry, pa! too ridiculous, a vaſt deal.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, huſſey—I feel I ſhall be miſerable without money, ſo I may as well marry and be miſerable with it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Cauſtic, only wait till to-morrow. I'll aſk every body to have me. Oh do! lud, I ſhall be under ſuch a ſtyle of obligation.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I'll make it a principle to pleaſe. Oh do!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Won't you? then you are an old wretch, a brute; and I hope, pa, if you marry, you'll be a brute: and (to Cauſtic) I vow I wiſh your gout may return, and ſhoot up into your wither'd head in ſuch a ſtyle— Yes, you may laugh— (ſobbing) but to be utterly ruined is extremely diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Oh, he's gone!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
Friend Toby, a lucky thought—I've hit
upon a wife for you. What ſay you to your viſitor, my couſin, Lady Sorrel? ſhe's virtuous.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: I've my doubts.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Oh fie! no, ſhe's extremely correct,—correct even to appearances. Her good conduct defies ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Then 'tis a bargain.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: With all my heart; and by giving you my hand, I give
sp.stage: (going to ſhake hands, a craſh is heard in the hot-houſe.)
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: More of my property going. I ſuppoſe ſome old blind tabby cat has got into my hot-houſe. Bring the blunderbuſs, will you?
sp.stage: (to officer)—(Lady Sorrel ſcreams, and Allſpice unlocks the door, and Lady Sorrel comes out.)

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Lady Sorrel!

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Hey day, couſin!

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I'm quite faint.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Reſt on me, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: The heat of the place.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: You ſeem rather warm. Pray, have you ſeen any thing of my dear friend, Mr. Daſhall?

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I, ſir? no.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: This has an odd appearance.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I'll explain it. Couſin, I went in to pull a bunch of grapes; and a booby of a ſervant paſſing by, lock'd the door.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
I'm ſatisfied. Well, couſin, I've got you a
huſband here. Nay, no bluſhing. You are too wiſe and too old for girliſh affectation. With my friend Toby, I give you thirty thouſand pounds, and as times go, a pretty honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Yes, my lady, an honeſt pretty man.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: And, friend Toby, with my couſin you have neither youth nor beauty, to be ſure; but abundance of chaſtity, virtue, and benevolence, ſo heaven—

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Zounds! what's that? I dare ſay, one of Cleme's puppy dogs.— (to officer) Go in, and pull him out by the cuff of the neck

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: I declare I'm quite faint again.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Let me ſupport you—I'll never leave you.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Have I found yon at laſt?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhall!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Who?
sp.stage: (Lets go Lady Sorrel, and runs to Daſhall, puts his hand into his pocket, and recovers his notes.)
sp.p: Give me my money, you villain! here it is. Oh, let me kiſs you, and lay you to my faithful breaſt.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: How have I been deceived!

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Mr. Cauſtic, you'll excuſe my marrying.— (to Daſhall) I can ſee your roguery without ſpectacles, you monopolizer of viliany! farewell to daſhing! Roger, bring me my wig and apron.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: My nephew! dare he come in my preſence? then you ſhall ſee me knock him down.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: No, no

div.stage: Enter TANGENT, followed by FAULKNER and JULIA.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In vain you fly me.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You diſtreſs me—I beg, ſir,—I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Never can my ſoul be ſatisfied, till my knees bend in gratitude—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Captain Faulkner! upon my ſoul, 'tis deviliſh hard to have one's feelings diſtreſſed, becauſe a man has done a trifling act—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: A trifling act! have you not redeemed me from priſon, from deſpair? have you not preſerved my Julia's honour?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Stand by. I don't think I ſhall knock him down.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: If I have been ſo fortunate, let my reward be the preſervation of that honour with my life, and for my life.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhou'd certainly feel proud of your alliance;—but you have a relation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: What, old uncle, ha, ha! I have certainly plagued him moſt confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I believe I'll knock him down

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: But, upon my honour, to make him unhappy, wou'd give me ſerious ſorrow. (Cauſtic drops his cane) Oh, ſir, give me but Julia Faulkner without fortune—

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: I forbid the banns.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I inſiſt.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p:
And, ſir, I inſiſt that you don't marry miſs
Faulkner without a fortune, but that you marry her with thirty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Moſt excellent uncle! my ſweeteſt Julia! and will you, ſir, forgive my follies?

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: Heartily, my boy. Frank, I can pardon the head for wandering, when I find the heart's at home.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Tangent, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Gently! while you were affluent, the elegant flavour of your Tokay kept down the coarſe twang of the borachio in your manners. But now you're poor, you'll be cut even by your brother ſwindlers.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Is not this the wretch—?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhou'd be happy to give you ſatisfaction; but you ſee I'm in cuſtody— (Faulkner going up to him) Officer, do your duty: why don't you ſecure me? I never deſpair—do you think this is the firſt time I've been in the Gazette? I've ſome irons in the fire yet.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: And if you want more irons, I cou'd recommend you to a pair that wou'd ſuit you exactly.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhall, are you going to town?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You may depend upon it, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sor.
sp.p: If you'll give me leave, I'll accompany you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Firſt let me thank you, madam, for the delicate anxiety you have ſhewn reſpecting me and this gentleman, and for your humanity in arreſting my father.

sp.speaker: Cauſtic.
sp.p: Did ſhe do that? abandoned hypocrite! leave my ſight.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Well, I bear no malice. Good bye to you all.
I ſay, Toby, won't you ſend ſome almonds and raiſins to Harriet?—ha, ha! Now to London, and my creditors, where I'll nobly give them fivepence halfpenny in the pound, and the jollieſt dinner the London Tavern can produce—Good bye to you, gigs! dam'me, I'll make a ſplaſh yet.
sp.stage: Exeunt Daſhall, Lady Sorrel, and Officer.

sp.speaker: Allſp.
sp.p: Put him in my horſe-pond. Let him make a ſplaſh there.

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: Pray, is Lady Sorrel—oh the devil—

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: Hold—oh dread not my perſonal chaſtiſement: your abject villainy protects you from that—

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: It is not the firſt time it has ſtood my friend.

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: Do you ſee this letter?

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: I certainly miſſed it, and am ready to refund.

sp.speaker: "Faulk.
sp.p: You diſgrace an honourable profeſſion, and are the vile exception to the liberal and noble character of your nation.

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p: Sir! I am worth twenty thouſand pounds, and am your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: "Tang.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: "M'Query.
sp.p:
Take care what you ſay, young gentleman—don't you libel an attorney—'tis the moſt heinous crime—the devil a lawyer will plead your cauſe for you; but the whole battalion of the black badgers will open upon you, and tell you that libelling an attorney ſtrikes at the root of humanity; it
tears out the vitals exiſtence; it ſhivers the adamantine bands of ſociety; it makes curds and whey of the milk of human kindneſs; it convulſes and confuſes, and diſturbs and diſtorts—Oh! whatever you do, never libel an attorney.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, my Julia has made you a convert.

sp.speaker: Cauſt.
sp.p: She has indeed—and I beg pardon of her ſex, to whom ſhe this given this leſſon—that the affection and duty of a daughter is the beſt ſecurity for happineſs in a wife; and that filial affection and feminine diffidence is THE WAY TO GET MARRIED. As for you, nephew—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Sir, I've bade adieu to all my air-drawn fancies, except the woolſack, in which whim I will once more indulge, in the trembling hope, that our endeavours this night to pleaſe, have been crowned with your candid approbation. As many as are content ſay "Aye." — non-contents, "No." We flatter ourſelves the contents have it.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: Written by Captain TOPHAM. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.

sp.l: THE dubious title of our Play this night
Might fill mama with joy, or miſs with fright.
"The Way to get a Huſband," and what not;—
But are they worth the getting when they're got?
"Yes," cries bold miſs,—whom mother's kind rega ••
Has led, at young fourteen, to cock her card,
"Yes," cries bold miſs, "whate'er the formals ſay,
They are worth getting, and I know the way.
—The way's up Bond-ſtreet! where we daily range,
Where ſauntering bloods crowd Faſhion's full exchange!
There (charming ſcene!) as undiſmay'd we ſtrut—
Dogs, miſſes, dukes, and draymen, meet full butt!
There, lounging arm in arm, half-booted crops,
With heads ſo dark, you'd ſwear they were—black mops!
There, muſlin petticoats with mud ſo lac'd▪
Here ſcarlet ſpencers with an inch of waiſt,
So ſcarlet all, my rouge they ſeem to ſcoff,
And look like lobſters with their tails cut off!
Here for a huſband is the ſcene to daſh,
Here for a town-bred miſs to—make a ſplaſh.
The plump, briſk widow takes a different road,
She cannot walk down Bond-ſtreet:—ſhe's a load!
Good ſixteen ſtone to carry—but yet ſtrong:
She rolls a wool-pack Venus,—broad as long!
Yet ſhe's a tender paſſion for the ſtage!
With her, dear private acting is the rage.
